Supercurrent as a Probe for Topological Superconductivity
in Magnetic Adatom Chains

Narayan Mohanta1,2, Arno P. Kampf1, and Thilo Kopp2 Center for Electronic Correlations and Magnetism, 1Theoretical Physics III, 2Experimental Physics VI, Institute of Physics, University of Augsburg, 86135 Augsburg, Germany
Abstract

A magnetic adatom chain, proximity coupled to a conventional superconductor with spin-orbit coupling, exhibits locally an odd-parity, spin-triplet pairing amplitude. We show that the singlet-triplet junction, thus formed, leads to a net spin accumulation in the near vicinity of the chain. The accumulated spins are polarized along the direction of the local ùêùùêù\mathbf{d}-vector for triplet pairing and generate an enhanced persistent current flowing around the chain. The spin polarization and the ‚Äúsupercurrent‚Äù reverse their directions beyond a critical exchange coupling strength at which the singlet superconducting order changes its sign on the chain. The current is strongly enhanced in the topological superconducting regime where Majorana bound states appear at the chain ends. The current and the spin profile offer alternative routes to characterize the topological superconducting state in adatom chains and islands.

Artificial lattices of magnetic adatoms, such as Fe, Cr or Gd, deposited on a spin-orbit coupled conventional superconductor, provide a versatile platform to realize Majorana bound states (MBS), locally accessible via scanning tunneling microscopy (STM)¬†PhysRevB.88.020407 ; Li2016 ; PhysRevLett.114.236803 ; Nadj-Perge602 ; Feldman2017 ; Pawlak2016 ; PhysRevLett.115.197204 ; Ruby_NanoLetters ; 2016arXiv160706353M . Unlike the heterostructure-based schemes¬†PhysRevLett.100.096407 ; PhysRevLett.105.077001 ; Mourik1003 ; 0295-5075-108-6-60001 , these adatom lattices can exhibit topological superconductivity (TSC) even in the absence of spin-orbit coupling (SOC) when the adatom moments within a chain form a real-space helix¬†PhysRevB.90.085124 ; PhysRevB.91.064505 ; PhysRevB.94.144509 . The adatoms act as magnetic impurities for the host superconductor and give rise to Yu-Shiba-Rushinov (YSR) states which hybridize to form a band dispersing within the energy gap of the superconductor¬†YU_acta1965 ; shiba_PTP1968 ; rushinov_JETP1969 ; 1367-2630-17-2-023051 . In suitable parameter regimes, SOC induces chiral TSC in the YSR impurity band¬†PhysRevB.93.014517 ; PhysRevB.88.155420 ; PhysRevLett.114.106801 ; PhysRevB.90.235433 ; PhysRevB.93.094508 ; PhysRevB.94.100501 ; 0953-8984-28-49-495703 ; PhysRevB.94.060501 ; PhysRevB.93.024507 ; PhysRevB.91.064502 ; PhysRevB.90.180503 ; PhysRevB.90.060507 ; PhysRevB.89.180505 ; PhysRevB.89.115109 ; Hui2015 ; PhysRevB.94.144509 . An adatom chain, therefore, mimics the physics of the one-dimensional Kitaev model¬†1063-7869-44-10S-S29 which contains isolated MBS at the ends of the chain. Experimental signatures for the possible existence of MBS on magnetic adatom chains were reported in recent STM experiments¬†Nadj-Perge602 ; Feldman2017 ; Pawlak2016 ; PhysRevLett.115.197204 ; Ruby_NanoLetters .

The broken inversion symmetry at an interface allows for a finite Rashba SOC. In the host sùë†s-wave superconductor, it combines with the local magnetic-exchange fields to produce spin-triplet, odd-parity, ¬±px+i‚Äãpyplus-or-minussubscriptùëùùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùë¶\pm~{}p_{x}+~{}ip_{y}-wave pairing at the adatom sites¬†2017arXiv170505378R . Conversely, the exchange field at the adatom sites suppresses the sùë†s-wave order parameter. Therefore, the adatom sites possess an admixture of spin-singlet sùë†s-wave and spin-triplet ¬±px+i‚Äãpyplus-or-minussubscriptùëùùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùë¶\pm~{}p_{x}+~{}ip_{y}-wave pairing. The spin-triplet correlations decay rapidly away from the adatom sites. An effective Josephson junction is, thus, formed in the vicinity of the adatom chain. A junction between a singlet and a triplet superconductor is predicted to accumulate spin because of the lifted spin-degeneracy of Andreev bound states (ABS)¬†PhysRevLett.101.187003 . Concomitantly, Rashba SOC generates a persistent current, carried by the YSR states, around the magnetic impurities; the currents flow orthogonal to the local spin polarization¬†PhysRevLett.115.116602 .

Here, we show that the two different mechanisms, viz. the singlet-triplet Josephson junction and Rashba SOC, jointly cooperate to reinforce spin accumulation and spontaneous current flow around the adatom chains. Due to Rashba SOC, the accumulated spin provides an additional source for a circulating current around the adatom chain. The accumulated spins are polarized perpendicular to the direction of current flow and parallel to the local ùêùùêù\mathbf{d}-vector of the triplet pairing amplitude. The sùë†s-wave pairing gap at the adatom site acquires a sign change as the YSR states undergo a parity-changing phase transition when the exchange coupling is tuned beyond a critical strength. The directions of both the spin-polarization and the current are reversed at the same exchange-coupling strength at which ŒîssubscriptŒîùë†\Delta_{s} changes sign. The current is significantly enhanced in the topological superconducting regime and, therefore, can be used as an alternative probe for the identification of TSC and the experimental verification of MBS.

The even-parity triplet pairing amplitude necessarily vanishes because of the broken time-reversal symmetry (TRS) at the impurity sites¬†Ebisu_ptep2016 .

The pair of YSR states, originating from a single magnetic impurity in an sùë†s-wave superconductor, emerge from the continuum of bulk states and move symmetrically closer in energy within the bulk superconducting gap, as the impurity moment J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS is increased. A quantum phase transition occurs with respect to the total spin of the ground state when they cross zero energy at a critical value Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S (=1/œÄ‚ÄãN0absent1ùúãsubscriptùëÅ0=1/\pi N_{0}, where N0subscriptùëÅ0N_{0} is the normal-state density of states at the Fermi level¬†RevModPhys.78.373 ). Beyond Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S, the YSR states move apart and approach the bulk continuum states. For an adatom chain, the YSR states form a band and, there is a range Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãS‚â§J‚ÄãS‚â§Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜùêΩùëÜsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S within which the YSR states remain close to zero energy. For a single magnetic impurity, the zero-energy level-crossing of the YSR states leads to a quantum phase transition as a localized quasiparticle excitation, with spin opposite to the impurity spin, is spontaneously created, forming an antiferromagnetic bound state with the impurity spin¬†SakuraiPTP1970 ; PhysRevB.55.12648 ; RevModPhys.78.373 ; 2017arXiv170505378R . The transition at Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S changes the total SzsubscriptùëÜùëßS_{z} of the ground state of the pairing Hamiltonian from Sz=0subscriptùëÜùëß0S_{z}=0 to ¬±1/2plus-or-minus12\pm 1/2, depending on the sign of JùêΩJ [see Supplemental Materials]. On the other hand, the sùë†s-wave pairing amplitude ŒîssubscriptŒîùë†\Delta_{s} at the impurity site sharply drops in magnitude at Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S and even encounters a sign change with respect to the bulk¬†RevModPhys.78.373 ; PhysRevB.95.104521 .

The triplet pairing amplitudes reflect the broken TRS at the adatom sites; they decay rapidly away from the chain sites [see Supplemental Materials]. Figs.¬†1(d) and 1(e) show the variation of the triplet pairing amplitudes with J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS. For a single impurity, these amplitudes reveal sharp jumps at Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S, along with a sign change in Im(ŒîœÉ‚ÄãœÉt‚Äã3)superscriptsubscriptŒîùúéùúéùë°3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}). For the adatom chain, the transition proceeds within the range Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãS‚â§J‚ÄãS‚â§Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜùêΩùëÜsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S, along with a maximum in Re(ŒîœÉ‚ÄãœÉt‚Äã1)superscriptsubscriptŒîùúéùúéùë°1(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t1}) and a sign change in Im(ŒîœÉ‚ÄãœÉt‚Äã3)superscriptsubscriptŒîùúéùúéùë°3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}) at Jc‚Äãs‚ÄãS=3.6subscriptùêΩùëêùë†ùëÜ3.6J_{cs}S=3.6 (denoted by a green vertical line in Figs.¬†1(d)-(e)). Hence, at Jc‚Äãs‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùë†ùëÜJ_{cs}S, there is a change in pairing symmetry from ¬±px+i‚Äãpyplus-or-minussubscriptùëùùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùë¶\pm p_{x}+ip_{y}-wave to ¬±px‚àíi‚Äãpyplus-or-minussubscriptùëùùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùë¶\pm p_{x}-ip_{y}-wave (¬±plus-or-minus\pm refers to pairing in ‚Üë‚Üë‚Üëabsent‚Üë\uparrow\uparrow and ‚Üì‚Üì‚Üìabsent‚Üì\downarrow\downarrow channels, respectively).

The triplet pairing is confined to the near vicinity of the adatom chain, and, therefore, an effective Josephson junction is formed between the chain region with pairing symmetry s¬±px+i‚Äãpyplus-or-minusùë†subscriptùëùùë•ùëñsubscriptùëùùë¶s\pm p_{x}+ip_{y} and the surrounding host superconductor with sùë†s-wave symmetry. Enhancing the triplet-pairing amplitude at the junction also increases the magnitude of the accumulated spins which are polarized in the direction of the local ùêùùêù\mathbf{d}-vector (in Balian-Werthamer representation) of the triplet pairing amplitude¬†PhysRevLett.101.187003 ; PhysRevB.80.024504 [see Supplemental Materials]. The spins near the chain point towards and away from the chain, respectively, for J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS below and above Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c2}S. The reorientation of the ùêùùêù\mathbf{d}-vector and the sign change in ŒîssubscriptŒîùë†\Delta_{s} both occur at the same critical impurity moment Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S for a single magnetic impurity. But for an adatom chain, the ùêùùêù\mathbf{d}-vector flips its direction at Jc‚Äãs‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùë†ùëÜJ_{cs}S while ŒîssubscriptŒîùë†\Delta_{s} changes sign at Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c2}S. The resultant spin profile near the chain is plotted in Figs.¬†2(a)-(c), in the three regimes, i.e. J‚ÄãS<Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜJS<J_{c1}S, Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãS‚â§J‚ÄãS‚â§Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜùêΩùëÜsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S, and J‚ÄãS>Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJS>J_{c2}S. To get quantitative information about the spin polarization and the value of J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS at which the spins flip their directions, we calculate Sy=1/2‚Äã‚ü®œÉy‚ü©subscriptùëÜùë¶12delimited-‚ü®‚ü©subscriptùúéùë¶S_{y}=1/2\langle\sigma_{y}\rangle at the neighboring sites below the adatom chain, with Ut=0subscriptùëàùë°0U_{t}=0 and with finite Utsubscriptùëàùë°U_{t}, and plot the average value with increasing J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS in Fig.¬†2(d). We observe a slight variation of SysubscriptùëÜùë¶S_{y} in the topological regime, that however decreases with increasing chain length. More importantly, SysubscriptùëÜùë¶S_{y}, with finite Utsubscriptùëàùë°U_{t}, acquires significantly larger values below Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜJ_{c1}S compared to that in the case of Ut=0subscriptùëàùë°0U_{t}=0. The amplitude of SysubscriptùëÜùë¶S_{y} follows the behavior of Im(ŒîœÉ‚ÄãœÉt‚Äã3)superscriptsubscriptŒîùúéùúéùë°3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}), suggesting a close connection between the accumulated spin and the triplet pairing amplitude. SysubscriptùëÜùë¶S_{y} changes sign at Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S for a single impurity and at Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c2}S for an adatom chain. The sign change in Im(ŒîœÉ‚ÄãœÉt‚Äã3)superscriptsubscriptŒîùúéùúéùë°3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}) at Jc‚Äãs‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùë†ùëÜJ_{cs}S is not reflected in SysubscriptùëÜùë¶S_{y} owing to the small amplitude of Im(ŒîœÉ‚ÄãœÉt‚Äã3)superscriptsubscriptŒîùúéùúéùë°3(\Delta_{\sigma\sigma}^{t3}) near Jc‚ÄãssubscriptùêΩùëêùë†J_{cs}. The exchange coupling jointly with Rashba SOC control the sign-change in SysubscriptùëÜùë¶S_{y} at Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c2}S when ŒîssubscriptŒîùë†\Delta_{s} also changes sign.

Rashba SOC gives rise to an additional contribution to the paramagnetic current operator, the expectation value of which depends upon the magnetization profile. A magnetic impurity or a ferromagnetic island, proximity coupled to a superconductor, renders a finite spin polarization around the impurity or the island, giving rise to a SOC-driven current¬†PhysRevLett.115.116602 ; PhysRevB.92.214501 . Hence, the spin accumulation near the chain generates a current in the superconductor which circulates around the chain. Driving a current via magnetism is referred to as the magneto-electric effect¬†PhysRevB.72.172501 . The contribution to the current operator ùê£sS‚ÄãO‚ÄãC=(js‚Äãx,js‚Äãy)superscriptsubscriptùê£ùë†ùëÜùëÇùê∂subscriptùëóùë†ùë•subscriptùëóùë†ùë¶\mathbf{j}_{s}^{SOC}=(j_{sx},~{}j_{sy}) originating from Rashba SOC is given by

following the Peierls-factor derivation of Ref.¬†PhysRevB.47.7995 . The rising of Sx/ysubscriptùëÜùë•ùë¶S_{x/y} at sites next to the adatom chain, induced by the singlet-triplet junction, leads to an enhanced current around the chain as described in Fig.¬†3. For a single magnetic impurity, the current ùê£ssubscriptùê£ùë†\mathbf{j}_{s} drops to a large negative value and changes its sense of circulation at Jc‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëêùëÜJ_{c}S where ŒîssubscriptŒîùë†\Delta_{s} changes sign. However, for an adatom chain, ùê£ssubscriptùê£ùë†\mathbf{j}_{s} rises to higher values at Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜJ_{c1}S (a few percent of the critical current ùê£s‚Äãc=2‚Äãe‚ÄãŒî/œÄ‚Äã‚Ñèsubscriptùê£ùë†ùëê2ùëíŒîùúãPlanck-constant-over-2-pi\mathbf{j}_{sc}=2e\Delta/\pi\hbar for the host superconductor¬†PhysRevB.49.6841 ), decreases non-monotonically and finally reverses its propagation direction at Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c2}S as shown in Fig.¬†3(a)-(d). The non-monotonic behavior of ùê£ssubscriptùê£ùë†\mathbf{j}_{s} between Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜJ_{c1}S and Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c2}S, including the steps, may be envisaged as a conjugate effect of (i) decrease in SysubscriptùëÜùë¶S_{y} of the accumulated spins and (ii) the step-wise increase in total SzsubscriptùëÜùëßS_{z} of the superconductor. The current is carried by the YSR states around the chain.

The magnetic-adatom chains have certainly received particular attention because of the existence of MBS at the chain ends. However, as our results demonstrate, the physics of the adatom chains contains far more intriguing aspects which originate from Rashba SOC. The accumulated spin polarization and the spin-triplet pairing amplitudes can possibly be detected by local spin-resolved probes with STM techniques¬†2017arXiv170100822G , while the orbital magnetic moment of the persistent current around the adatom chains should be measurable using scanning SQUID sensors. The existence of the MBS, as inferred from STM experiments, appears still ambiguous primarily because of experimental challenges in disentangling the MBS from the YSR states near zero energy¬†1402-4896-2015-T164-014008 . The simultaneous detection of the circulating currents would therefore provide a further piece of evidence in support of TSC and the interpretation of the STM signals in favor of MBS.

For a particular choice of adatoms (Fe or Co) and their configuration on the surface, the parameters JùêΩJ and SùëÜS are fixed and it is not possible to explore different phases in one experiment. The issue could be circumvented by applying a homogeneous magnetic field to rotate the spin polarization of the adatoms. In the current analysis, we assumed the adatom spins to point towards the zùëßz-direction i.e. perpendicular to the surface of the superconductor. Since Rashba SOC breaks the SU(2) symmetry, the YSR states depend on the polar angle Œ∏ùúÉ\theta of the adatom spins and a topological phase transition can be induced by tuning Œ∏ùúÉ\theta¬†PhysRevLett.114.236804 ; Loder2015 . A magnetic-field rotation experiment may thereby tune to the topological regime using the circulating current as a probe. The phenomena, identified here, are equally applicable to islands of adatoms where MBS convert to edge-bound modes.

II S2. Majorana bound states in the topological superconducting phase

As made evident in Fig.¬†1 in the main text, the magnetic adatom chain exhibits topological superconductivity within the range Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãS‚â§J‚ÄãS‚â§Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜùêΩùëÜsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S. To verify the Majorana bound states (MBS) appearing within this range of J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS, we plot the LDOS profile corresponding to the lowest pair of energy eigenvalues for a square lattice of size 61√ó61616161\times 61 with a 505050-sites long adatom chain for J‚ÄãS=1ùêΩùëÜ1JS=1 (non-topological phase) in Fig.¬†F1(a) and for J‚ÄãS=3ùêΩùëÜ3JS=3 (topological phase) in Fig.¬†F1(b).

For J‚ÄãS=1ùêΩùëÜ1JS=1, the LDOS profile is centered in the middle of the chain indicating that the Yu-Shiba-Rushinov (YSR) states are extended within the impurity chain. Instead, for J‚ÄãS=3ùêΩùëÜ3JS=3, the lowest-energy pair (¬±2.8√ó10‚àí4plus-or-minus2.8superscript104\pm 2.8\times 10^{-4}) comes close to zero and the LDOS is concentrated at the two ends of the adatom chain. These sharp features at the chain-ends are the signatures of localized MBS. The tiny energy gap (‚àº10‚àí4similar-toabsentsuperscript104\sim 10^{-4} for Nimp=50subscriptùëÅimp50N_{\text{imp}}=50) between the two MBS arises because the two MBS which decay exponentially with distance, but hybridize in the middle of the chain. This hybridization gap reduces with increasing chain length.

III S3. Spin-triplet pairing at the adatom chain

To study the spatial confinement of the induced triplet pairing amplitude, we plot in Fig.¬†F2 the profile of the magnetization, the singlet and triplet pairing amplitudes in the two-dimensional lattice plane.

We find that the induced triplet pairing is confined to the vicinity of the adatom chain and die off quickly at sites further away from the chain. The sùë†s-wave pairing gap ŒîssubscriptŒîùë†\Delta_{s} is significantly suppressed because of the local magnetization along the chain, as shown in Fig.¬†F2(a)-(b). Interestingly, the triplet order parameters Re(Œî‚Üë‚Üët,1)superscriptsubscriptŒî‚Üëabsent‚Üëùë°1(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t,1}) and Im(Œî‚Üë‚Üët,3)superscriptsubscriptŒî‚Üëabsent‚Üëùë°3(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t,3}) reveal maximum amplitudes at the ends of the chain only in the topological superconducting regime, as shown in Fig.¬†F2(c)-(d). It was, in fact, proposed that MBS on the boundary of topological superconductors have universal spin-triplet correlations¬†Liu_PRB2015 . There is a sign change in Re(Œî‚Üë‚Üët,1)superscriptsubscriptŒî‚Üëabsent‚Üëùë°1(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t,1}) at the two ends of the chain indicating the realization of chiral pùëùp-wave triplet pairing. The results demonstrate that a mixed singlet-triplet pairing is realized in the chain and, thus an effective Josephson junction is formed in the vicinity of the chain. The consequences of the Josephson junction is discussed in the main text.

In order to check the nature of the induced triplet pairing in the adatom chain, we plot the logarithm of the triplet pairing amplitude Œît=Re‚Äã(Œî‚Üë‚Üët‚Äã1)subscriptŒîùë°ResuperscriptsubscriptŒî‚Üëabsent‚Üëùë°1\Delta_{t}=\text{Re}(\Delta_{\uparrow\uparrow}^{t1}) with Utsubscriptùëàùë°U_{t} in Fig.¬†F3.

In the Ut‚Üí0‚Üísubscriptùëàùë°0U_{t}\rightarrow 0 limit, log(ŒîtsubscriptŒîùë°\Delta_{t}) approaches a finite, small number. The results establish that the induced triplet pairing on the adatom chain is of conventional character.

IV S4. Variation of the occupation number

With increasing impurity moment J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS, the total SzsubscriptùëÜùëßS_{z} of the superconductor, for a single impurity, increases by ¬±1/2plus-or-minus12\pm 1/2 (depending on the sign of JùêΩJ) at JcsubscriptùêΩùëêJ_{c}. For an adatom chain, the total SzsubscriptùëÜùëßS_{z} increases in steps of height 1/2121/2 within the range Jc‚Äã1‚ÄãS‚â§J‚ÄãS‚â§Jc‚Äã2‚ÄãSsubscriptùêΩùëê1ùëÜùêΩùëÜsubscriptùêΩùëê2ùëÜJ_{c1}S\leq JS\leq J_{c2}S to the final value ¬±(1/2)‚ÄãNimpplus-or-minus12subscriptùëÅimp\pm(1/2)N_{\text{imp}}, as described in the main text. This increase corresponds to the spontaneous creation of quasiparticle excitations.

However, the quasiparticle excitations in BdG evaluation of the pairing Hamiltonian always come in pairs. This is reflected in FIG.¬†F5 which shows the variation of the occupation numbers n‚Üësubscriptùëõ‚Üën_{\uparrow} and n‚Üìsubscriptùëõ‚Üìn_{\downarrow} of up- and down-spin electrons, respectively, with J‚ÄãSùêΩùëÜJS.
